**METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART ACQUIRES RARE JANSSEN MASTERPIECE**

New York, NY - In a major coup for the art world, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has announced the acquisition of "A Woman Slicing Bread," a stunning oil on canvas painting by Dutch master Johannes Christiaan Janssen. The museum's latest addition is a significant milestone in its ongoing efforts to expand its collection of 19th-century European art. "We are thrilled to welcome 'A Woman Slicing Bread' to the Met's esteemed collection," said Dr. Sophia Patel, Curator of European Painting and Sculpture. "Janssen's work is a testament to the beauty and simplicity of everyday life, and this piece is a remarkable example of his skill and artistry." Painted in 1885, "A Woman Slicing Bread" depicts a serene domestic scene, with a young woman intently focused on slicing a loaf of bread in a warm, sunlit kitchen. The painting's intricate details, from the delicate folds of the woman's apron to the crusty texture of the bread, showcase Janssen's mastery of light and shadow. The acquisition is the result of a year-long negotiation between the Met and a private collector, who wished to remain anonymous. The painting was previously on loan to the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam, where it was seen by millions of visitors. "We are grateful to the collector for entrusting us with this national treasure," said Met Director, Max Hollein. "This acquisition is a testament to the Met's commitment to preserving and showcasing the world's greatest works of art." The painting will go on display in the Met's European Wing, alongside other notable works by Janssen's contemporaries, including Monet and Renoir. Visitors can expect to see "A Woman Slicing Bread" as part of the museum's permanent collection starting next month. In related news, the Met has announced a series of events and exhibitions celebrating the acquisition, including a lecture series on Janssen's life and work, as well as a family-friendly workshop on still-life painting.
